headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Jan. 31, 2012

headline: Sadanand Dhume: Weaning India Off Iran
summary: Cooperating with U.S.-led sanctions against Tehran would bring New Delhi long-term dividends.

headline: US Watchdog to Examine Freddie Mac Use of Floaters
summary: A federal watchdog said Tuesday it would examine Freddie Mac's use of a mortgage derivative amid allegations that such investments gave the mortgage company an incentive to prevent borrowers from refinancing their home loans.

headline: Stocks Fall at Close of Banner Month
summary: A disappointing round of economic data weighed on U.S. stocks Tuesday, but major indexes still posted the largest January gains in 15 years.

headline: Jenkins: The Wireless Equivalent of Fracking
summary: The Wi-Fi revolution shows how far the FCC is behind the curve.

headline: Knicks Blow Out the Pistons
summary: Carmelo Anthony, in his return from injury, scores 25 points and dishes out six assists in a winning effort.

headline: Devils Beat Rangers, 4-3
summary: New Jersey's David Clarkson ties the game in the final minute, while Ilya Kovalchuk scores the lone goal in the shootout, beating Rangers backup Martin Biron.

headline: Seagate Preps For Drive Shortages Amid Flooding
summary: Seagate predicted long-term changes to the disk-drive industry because of Thailand's catastrophic flooding, which the company said will extend the drive shortages that have boosted its own pricing and bottom line.

headline: Rinehart Buys Nearly 8% of Fairfax
summary: Australian mining billionaire Gina Rinehart's raid on Fairfax Media has gained her almost 8% of Australia's oldest newspaper publisher, with A$152 million worth of shares changing hands.

headline: Congress to Block Tighter Rules for Batteries on Cargo Flights
summary: Lawmakers agreed on a bill reauthorizing the Federal Aviation Administration for four years, reaching a deal on a host of issues including a provision designed to block tougher rules on shipping rechargeable batteries on cargo planes.

headline: Warner to Fight EMI Deal
summary: Edgar Bronfman Jr., chairman of Warner Music, voiced strong opposition to Universal Music's plan to buy EMI, saying it would lead to too much market concentration.

headline: News Corp.'s Carey Says Antipiracy Issue Got 'Turned Upside-Down'
summary: News Corp. operating chief Chase Carey said the debate surrounding proposed antipiracy legislation got twisted as media companies failed to see the "viral aspect" of the issue.

headline: How to Finance Your Start-Up Without Tapping Home Equity
summary: Consider these five alternatives for raising capital to get a new business off the ground.

headline: Sprint Gives LightSquared Extension For FCC Clearance
summary: Sprint Nextel granted LightSquared a new six-week extension to get Federal Communications Commission clearance to operate its planned nationwide fourth-generation network.

headline: No Medal of Honor for Washington
summary: Regarding John White's(op-ed, Jan. 28): It was interesting to read that Mr. White wants to have a medal of honor awarded to George Washington. However, I always thought that this medal was intended to recognize the incredible courage of common warriors who otherwise would remain anonymous.

headline: USDA Eases Stance on Contracts
summary: The USDA withdrew a proposal to change its procurement contracts after business groups raised concerns it would increase their labor headaches.

headline: Law Firms Pursue Growth by Poaching
summary: Law-firm partner defections rose last year, and legal experts predict the trend will continue this year as firms compete for established books of business amid sagging demand for legal services.

headline: CIT Net Slides 59%
summary: CIT Group showed more signs that efforts to reduce costs and build up its business are paying off, even though its fourth-quarter profit declined 59%.

headline: Martha Stewart Eyes Web
summary: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, losing its show on the Hallmark Channel, is examining other programming outlets, including on the Web.

headline: Treasurys Notch Fifth Consecutive Gain
summary: Month-end buyers spurred Treasury prices higher, helping the market recover from overnight losses and end January with a bang on five consecutive positive sessions.

headline: Biogen's Net Rises 25%
summary: Biogen Idec's earnings rose 25%, fueled by rising sales of multiple-sclerosis drugs.

headline: Brazilian Banks' Websites Face Hacker Attacks
summary: A day after attacking the website of Banco Itaú, hackers on Tuesday attacked the website of Banco Bradesco and vowed to continue the disruptions all week.

headline: Andrew Tyrie: Send In the IMF
summary: The Fund should be given the mandate and resources to sort out the euro zone.

headline: Crude Ends Slightly Lower
summary: Crude-oil futures settled below $99 a barrel ahead of inventory data expected to show a rise in already high U.S. crude-oil inventories.

headline: Renewables Are Still Germany's Way Forward
summary: Responding to "Germany's Solar Crack-Up" (Review & Outlook, Jan. 25).

headline: ADM's Net Slides 89%
summary: Archer Daniels Midland's earnings plummeted 89% on weakness at its grain-processing and trading businesses and a charge from the shuttering of a bioplastics venture.

headline: Clear Channel Investment in Seacrest to Fund TV Production
summary: Clear Channel Chief Executive Robert Pittman said his company's planned investment in Ryan Seacrest Productions was motivated by the "American Idol" host's "ambition and talent."

headline: Hulu Stresses Original Shows
summary: The CEO of Hulu says that a plan to invest in original shows will help the video website distinguish itself in an increasingly competitive market.

headline: Neil Young Defends Both Record Companies and Piracy
summary: Musician Neil Young offered a vigorous defense of record companies, followed by an equally vigorous defense of piracy.

headline: Gold Adds Small Gains
summary: Gold futures carved out a slight gain as weaker U.S. data and a declining euro tempered early gains. Gold for April delivery settled at its highest level in nearly eight weeks.

headline: FCC Approves Changes to Phone-Subsidy Program
summary: The FCC approved changes to a federal phone subsidy program for low-income Americans to help them afford broadband service.

headline: Canada Expands Iran Sanctions
summary: Canada said it is expanding its sanctions against Iranian companies and individuals, part of an effort in North America and Europe to pressure Iran to return to negotiations over the its nuclear program.

headline: Cruise Official Pressed Over Ship Disaster
summary: Italian prosecutors questioned a key official of Costa Crociere, the operator of the shipwrecked Costa Concordia, as the company faced mounting scrutiny over its conduct.

headline: Newt's Next Move
summary: Where does Newt go from here?

headline: TARP to See $23 Billion Hitas AIG, GM Stocks Stagnate
summary: The Troubled Asset Relief Program will log losses of $23 billion in fiscal 2012, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, in a reversal of $37 billion in gains recorded in the prior year.

headline: Toshiba, Fujitsu Post Losses
summary: Toshiba and Fujitsu posted quarterly losses and cut their forecasts for the fiscal year as Thailand's flooding aggravated troubles from the strong yen.

headline: Daiichi Sankyo Logs Loss
summary: Daiichi Sankyo Co. said it fell into the red for the fiscal third quarter and further lowered its full-year outlook, hurt again by the stubbornly strong yen and legal costs associated with its Indian unit.

headline: RadioShack Shares Plummet on Warning
summary: RadioShack said it expects its fourth-quarter results below analysts' expectations, citing the underperformance of the company's Sprint postpaid-wireless business and unanticipated changes in Sprint Nextel's customer and credit models. Shares were down 19% in after-hours trading Monday.

headline: Mattel Profit Up 14%
summary: Mattel said strong holiday demand for Barbie and American Girl dolls helped push up its earnings in the latest quarter. The toy maker also increased its dividend 35%.

headline: Trouble in Syria
summary: Violence spilled into Damascus and environs this week as the U.N. continued talks on a Security Council resolution calling for a peaceful departure of Syrian President Bashar Assad.

headline: McGraw-Hill's Net Jumps
summary: McGraw-Hill's profit rose 39% despite costs tied to the company's planned split into two separate entities. It also reported improving sales in its long-struggling education business.

headline: Kaufman Bros. Closes Shop
summary: Kaufman Bros. joined the ranks of small securities firms to cease operations or scale back as low trading volume and low volatility wreak havoc in the industry.

headline: Merkel Seeks to Boost Europe, China Ties
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will use her trip to China to lobby for trust in the euro zone, which is working to solve its debt crisis by imposing tougher budget rules and implementing bigger rescue funds.

headline: Moody's Cuts Qantas
summary: Qantas Airways' credit rating was downgraded by Moody's, partly because of the impact of higher fuel prices, but the airline managed to retain investment-grade status.

headline: China Gets Tough on Superships
summary: Beijing tightened scrutiny on supersize iron-ore freighters, potentially complicating efforts by Brazil's Vale to gain access to the lucrative market.

headline: Australia House Prices Down
summary: Australian monthly house prices declined once again in December, adding to concerns among banks and property firms that a deterioration in prices across the country will resume this year.

headline: Say No to a U.S.-China Trade War
summary: China will not tolerate American protectionism.

headline: Don't Blame Singh Alone
summary: A broader, less pessimistic view of India's situation is in order.

headline: Taiwan Trade Isn't Mainland Biased
summary: President Ma Ying-jeou has successfully facilitated trade with many countries.

headline: Malaysia's Reforms are Real
summary: Prime Minister Najib Razak has stuck to his promises and will continue to.

headline: Ally Takes Big Charge for Foreclosure Matters
summary: Ally Financial said Tuesday that it will record a charge of about $270 million in the fourth quarter for expected regulatory penalties related to alleged foreclosure abuses.

headline: Europe Pact Helps Asia Stocks
summary: Most Asian markets climbed on cautious buying after EU nations endorsed a fiscal-discipline pact, with Japanese stocks squeezing a small rise out of some positive data and earnings news. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.1%.

headline: European M&A Has Yet to Take Wing
summary: This has been the weakest January for European mergers and acquisitions since 2003. With markets still uncertain and shareholders wary of companies splashing their cash, a deal surge may be a while off yet.

headline: U.S. Steel's Loss Narrows
summary: U.S. Steel posted a narrower loss on continued strength in its tubular-steel unit, though its flat-rolled steel and European businesses posted losses.

headline: Chinese Steelmakers' Shares Tumble
summary: Profit warnings from Angang Steel and Maanshan Iron & Steel sent their shares plunging, as investors fretted that a softening property market and higher raw-material costs would continue to weigh on profitability.

headline: Governments Need Urgent Health Check
summary: Government finances in many advanced economies are already ailing. But unless politicians grasp the urgency of health-care reform soon, public balance sheets could look far sicklier.

headline: Australia's Banks Will Feel the Squeeze
summary: Home or abroad, Australian banks can't catch a break.

headline: Japanese Games Fight Deepens
summary: A legal brouhaha between Japan's two leading mobile videogame platforms just became messier. DeNA, which was sued by Gree last year, filed a countersuit Tuesday.

headline: Nokia Siemens to Cut 4,100 Jobs
summary: Network equipment vendor Nokia Siemens Networks plans to cut jobs in Germany and Finland as part of its massive restructuring plan announced in November.

headline: ThyssenKrupp to Sell Steel Unit
summary: ThyssenKrupp agreed to sell its Inoxum stainless-steel division to Finland's Outokumpu in a deal valuing the operations at $3.55 billion.

headline: IDBI Bank Profit Falls 9.7%
summary: India's IDBI Bank's third-quarter net profit declined 9.7%, hurt by higher interest costs, as it joined its state-run peers in reporting weak quarterly results.

headline: Advisers: India Growth to Slow to About 7%
summary: India's economic growth will slow to about 7% this fiscal year through March but will pick up next year as inflation eases and industrial activity improves, two top government advisers said.

headline: Novartis CEO Looks to Mitigate Currency Risk
summary: Currency volatility will be a fact of life for at least the next five years and companies need to prepare strategies for protecting themselves against that risk, said Novartis Chief Executive Joe Jimenez.

headline: Scaled-Down IPO Marks Weak Start in Shanghai
summary: China's IPO market it getting off to a slow start this year, with China Communications Construction slashing the size of its planned Shanghai listing.

headline: ICICI Bank Profit Up 20%
summary: India's ICICI Bank beat market expectations with a 20% rise in its fiscal third-quarter net profit, thanks to strong demand for loans and lower provisioning against bad loans.

headline: India Develops Index for Global Investors
summary: India's finance ministry has developed an index that seeks to compare sovereign ratings of several nations to help global investors decide where to put money, the country's chief economic adviser said.

headline: India Revokes Coal Price Increase
summary: India has revoked a recent increase in coal prices due to opposition from consumers, including power and cement companies, in a move that will weigh on the financial performance of state-run monopoly Coal India.

headline: Peugeot May Adjust India Plans
summary: French auto maker PSA Peugeot Citroën said it may adjust its schedule for building a car manufacturing factory in India.

headline: U.K. Consumers Repay Debt, Money Supply Shrinks
summary: U.K. households made a record repayment of personal loans and credit card bills in December, heightening fears the U.K. may slip back into recession.

headline: Aegis Plans U.S. Listing
summary: India's Aegis, owned by the Essar Group, is looking to raise between $350 million and $400 million from a U.S. initial public offering, following a sale of some shares to individual investors first.

headline: Indian Shares End Higher
summary: Indian shares ended higher Tuesday, with bank stocks leading the charge after index heavyweight ICICI Bank beat estimates with strong quarterly earnings growth.

headline: China Rushes to Clean Up Cadmium Spill
summary: A spill of highly toxic, cancer-causing cadmium, a metal used in rechargeable batteries, has polluted a long stretch of two rivers in southern China, leading officials to warn some 3.7 million people to avoid drinking the water.

headline: TVS Profit Misses Forecast
summary: TVS Motor, India's third-largest two-wheeler maker by sales, posted a lower-than-expected 1.4% rise in its third-quarter net profit as demand for its motorcycles fell.

headline: Mizuho Net Profit Falls by a Third
summary: Mizuho Financial Group said its group net profit fell by more than a third in the first nine months of its fiscal year on billion-dollar-plus valuation losses from its equity holdings and an incoming corporate tax shake-up.

headline: RBI: More CRR Cuts an Option to Boost Liquidity
summary: India's central bank won't shy away from cutting banks' minimum cash requirement again to ease liquidity in the banking system, but such a move isn't imminent, a top official said.

headline: Tokyo's Fiscal Woes Don't Lead To Rome
summary: Comparing Japan to Italy is neat shorthand for measuring the Asian nation's debt load. It's also misleading.

headline: Turkey Hawkish on Inflation
summary: Turkey's central bank issued a hawkish inflation report, revising its price forecasts sharply higher and stressing that policy should remain tight to counter price pressures and external risks.

headline: Tokyo Plans Its Own Gas Plant
summary: Japan's capital city government is planning to generate its own electricity to cover basic public services in an effort to avoid the recurrence of rolling blackouts that followed the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami.

headline: German Retail Sales Fall
summary: Germany's retail sales fell in December, but were still higher for the year as a whole, while French consumer spending dropped unexpectedly.

headline: ARM Net Rises on Gadget Demand
summary: Microchip designer ARM posted a sharp rise in fourth-quarter net profit, underpinned by strong demand for smartphones and tablets.

headline: Korean Air Swings to Full-Year Loss
summary: Korean Air Lines said it swung to a net loss last year because of a surge in jet fuel expenses, a weaker local currency and sluggish cargo demand, though its fourth-quarter net profit jumped due to foreign-exchange gains.

headline: Hong Kong Braces for Bank Layoffs
summary: Hong Kong is bracing for more finance-sector job cuts as Western banks scale back their Asian expansion amid the fallout from Europe's debt crisis and a generally weaker global economy.

headline: Japan Output Beats Forecasts
summary: Japanese industrial production rose 4% in December from the previous month, as the impact of the flooding in Thailand on Japanese manufacturers receded.

headline: Daiwa Securities Posts Fourth Straight Loss
summary: Japanese brokerage firm Daiwa Securities Group posted its fourth straight quarterly loss and said it would slash costs and jobs more aggressively as it reels from a risk-averse business climate amid the euro-zone debt crisis.

headline: Air India, Kingfisher Owe $300 Million to Airport Authority
summary: Loss-making carriers Air India and Kingfisher owe a combined 14.35 billion rupees (about $300 million) to the Airports Authority of India, the chairman of the state-run airport operator said.

headline: South Korea Says Inflation Top Priority
summary: South Korea's President said the government must anchor inflation even at the expense of weaker growth, just as December's industrial output unexpectedly contracted.

headline: Cruise Crash Cuts Carnival Profit
summary: Carnival Corp. estimates that the Italian cruise ship wreck will lower net income by $155 million to $175 million in fiscal 2012. Passenger bookings fell in January, but Carnival said it doesn't expect a significant long-term impact on its business.

headline: Twitter CEO Explains New Policy
summary: Twitter's recently announced censorship policy was meant to be a transparent way to handle government requests for the removal of certain content, not a signal that the message site was proactively monitoring its "tweets," Chief Executive Dick Costolo said.

headline: H-P Payments for Intel Chip Detailed
summary: Hewlett-Packard paid Intel hundreds of millions of dollars to keep developing chips for the high-end H-P server systems at the heart of a lawsuit with rival Oracle Corp., according to an Oracle court filing

headline: Fund Raising Shows a Shift By McMahon
summary: This time around, as Linda McMahon runs to replace retiring Sen. Joseph Lieberman, the former World Wrestling Entertainment CEO is taking a different tack: sticking her hand out to ask voters for money.

headline: News & Trends in Management
summary: Move over M.B.A.s, engineers are far more prevalent in companies' top ranks, a new study says. Plus, CEOs are making transparency a priority.

headline: U.K. Pension Savings Questioned
summary: The U.K. government's proposed reforms to public sector pensions are unlikely to save any money over the long-term, a report from an influential think tank said.

headline: Sudan Says It Freed Some Chinese Workers
summary: Sudan said it rescued 14 Chinese nationals held captive by rebels there since Saturday, but some Chinese media reports on Tuesday cast doubt on the Sudanese statements.

headline: Two Toddlers Left on Street
summary: A 26-year-old mother of three was arrested Monday after police said she abandoned two of her children on a Brooklyn street on Sunday holding nothing but diapers.

headline: Agencies, Drug Makers, Gates Target 10 Diseases
summary: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, government aid agencies and a clutch of drug companies pledged nearly $800 million and an increased drug supply toward a new push to wipe out 10 tropical diseases by 2020.

headline: Queries on RBS Chief's Fate
summary: The political fracas that pressed Royal Bank of Scotland's chief executive to turn down his 2011 bonus has raised questions about how long he will remain at the helm.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Hillary
summary: OUTSIDE THE BOX  By Pete du Pont  Why she might want to run for vice president—and why she might not.

headline: Tutor Network Scores to Grow
summary: Aristotle Circle, a national network of admissions experts based in New York, has purchased one of the largest peer tutoring companies in the country and plans to double its size by the end of the year.

headline: Santorum Returns to Campaigning after Daughter's Health Improves
summary: Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum said his 3-year-old daughter, who was hospitalized with pneumonia over the weekend, had experienced a turnaround and he would resume campaigning.

headline: Store Brands Flex Muscle
summary: Consumers are developing loyalty to stores' private-label brands, which have improved in quality and packaging in recent years. Often, stores' exclusive lines are no longer competing on price

headline: Converted Cotswolds Water Mill
summary: This six-bedroom historic home in the heart of the English Cotswolds was in use as a mill from 1689 until 1950.

headline: Philips Swings to Net Loss
summary: Dutch electronics giant Philips swung to a net loss as weak market conditions in Europe and losses from discontinued operations—notably its TV business—weighed heavily.

section: New York House of the Day
headline: Brownstone With a Secret Side
summary: Most New Yorkers see the city's venerable brownstones as architectural portals to the past. One unusual example in the East Village includes a folding facade, bringing the historic home into the future.

headline: Syrian Forces Battle Amid U.N. Talks
summary: Syria's military widened an offensive to reclaim a belt around Damascus, as talks gained pace at the United Nations over a Security Council resolution that aims to condemn Syria for the violence.

headline: Portugal Needs Help to Prove Market Wrong
summary: The market has made up its mind on Portugal. But the country isn't necessarily doomed to a debt restructuring—as long as the euro zone has learned from Greece and steps in to fill the gap.

headline: Cairo Embassy Shelters Americans
summary: A group of Americans who have been prohibited from leaving Egypt have taken refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Cairo, in the midst of a crackdown on pro-democracy and human-rights organizations.

headline: Arthur Laffer: Why Gingrich's Tax Plan Beats Romney's
summary: Newt's flat tax would do a lot more to attract capital, spur growth and reduce compliance costs.

headline: 'Rank and Yank' Still Liked by Some
summary: Forced ranking—rigorous employee rankings that reward top performers—seems to have fallen out of favor, but champions of the controversial system remain.

headline: Universal Health Care And U.S. Competitors
summary: Edwin J. Feulner uses whatever logic he can muster to support his argument that President Obama and the Democrats are the root cause for the U.S.'s decline in the ratings of economic freedom ("A Step Backward for Economic Freedom in 2012," op-ed, Jan. 12).

headline: New Construction Slid 31% in 2011
summary: New York City's construction industry was dealt another tough year as the value of construction projects that began in 2011 sank 31% compared with 2010.

headline: Puck Honored by Beard
summary: The James Beard Foundation's Lifetime Achievement award this year will go to Wolfgang Puck, whose menu for The Academy Awards Governors Ball is almost as eagerly anticipated as the awards themselves.

headline: Florida Race Ends on a Hostile Note
summary: Presidential candidates Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich battled Monday over who had the best credentials to bring change to Washington, as both spent a final day looking for votes ahead of Florida's Republican primary.

headline: Leaner Pfizer Expects Clean Bill of Health
summary: Since CEO Ian Read took over a little more than a year ago, Pfizer has shed billions of dollars in corporate flab. It may get a surprisingly clean bill of health at its annual checkup Tuesday morning.

headline: The Yogi Berra School Of Management
summary: Regarding the quote from Delta Air Lines' senior VP: "There are a certain amount of people in long-haul markets willing to pay extra to get there quickly, even though it takes a long time." ("The World's Longest Flight, in Coach," The Middle Seat, Jan. 19.) Yogi Berra couldn't have said it any better.

headline: Starbucks Enters India
summary: Starbucks made its much-awaited entry into India through a joint venture with the Tata Group to tap into the growing trend for coffee drinking in Asia's third-largest economy.

headline: Church Clerk Charged With $1 Million Theft
summary: An Archdiocese of New York clerk has been arrested on charges of manipulating the church's accounts payable system to steal more than $1 million.

headline: Verizon's Tangled Web
summary: As Verizon Communications pushes for more cable-television and high-speed Internet subscribers, a new competitor is emerging: its own subsidiary, Verizon Wireless.

headline: Media Innovation Goes Bicoastal
summary: A $30 million gift from legendary editor Helen Gurley Brown will fund a joint program between Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism and Stanford University's School of Engineering.

headline: Facebook Widens Lead in Display Ads
summary: Facebook is widening its lead over Yahoo in the online display-advertising market ahead of an expected filing for an initial public offering.

headline: Groupon CEO Takes On Critics
summary: Groupon Chief Executive Andrew Mason wants to prove his company is worth the fuss after its roller-coaster ride to an initial public offering last year.

headline: The Placeholder Column
summary: When I got food poisoning over the weekend—at least I think it was food poisoning—and was too depleted after dragging myself off the bathroom floor to write a column for Monday's paper, a friend suggested Greater New York run a "Best Of" column.

headline: A Royal Lesson for RBS
summary: The sooner the British government relinquishes its stake in the bank, the better.

headline: Romney's Florida Lead Cuts Across Categories
summary: If the polls are right and the Sunshine State delivers the former Massachusetts governor a decisive win, his breadth of support could prove more telling than the margin of victory.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Jan. 31, 2012

headline: China Sees Shanghai as Hub
summary: China's top economic body set new targets for Shanghai to grow into a global financial hub. But the blueprint doesn't say when foreign firms will be allowed to list there.

headline: Eli Manning Has Never Been a 'Marlboro' Man
summary: Arriving in big brother Peyton's town, of course Giants quarterback Eli Manning was going to field questions about the Colts quarterback. And whether it was conscious or not, he did exact a little payback—by painting him in a less than flattering light.

headline: Moody's: MF Bet Was Surprise to It
summary: Moody's told a congressional subcommittee that the ratings firm didn't know about MF Global's huge bets on European sovereign bonds until three days before the downgrade that helped push the company into bankruptcy.

headline: Saudis Push Young People Into Jobs
summary: Saudi Arabia is taking steps to change a mindset left from the days when the oil kingdom's citizens were few and jobs were many: that its citizens take the cushiest jobs or take no jobs at all.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: A glimpse of teachers union power in New York City.

headline: CFTC to Step Up Focus on High-Frequency Trading
summary: The CFTC is planning to take a closer look at high-frequency trading, with an eye on getting a clearer understanding of how electronic trading affects commodity markets and participants.

headline: Europe Tightens Fiscal Ties
summary: European leaders agreed on a pact to move to closer fiscal union and signed off on details of a permanent bailout fund for the euro zone – yet Greece threw a shadow over the summit.

headline: Florida Vote Sets Stage for Final Push
summary: Braced for a drubbing in Florida, Newt Gingrich and his aides insist they see a path to the Republican presidential nomination despite losing momentum.

headline: Behind Claims of 'Fastest' Internet Speeds
summary: Many Internet service providers such as Verizon and Cablevision have laid claim to the title of "fastest" broadband speeds over the years. Who's right? It's complicated.

headline: Rising Income Is Saved, Not Spent
summary: Incomes ticked up in December but consumers chose to save instead of spend, suggesting a still-cautious outlook that likely has carried into 2012.

headline: The Dream Smasher
summary: British-born actor Jack Davenport discusses his new TV series "Smash," about a demanding director saddled with the task of choreographing and helming a Marilyn Monroe-based musical for Broadway.

headline: Margin Call for China Bank Investors
summary: In China, the rapid rise of wealth-management products means banks are forced to compete for funds by offering interest rates that exceed the benchmark deposit rate. That threatens to squeeze profitability. It may also lead to a buildup of risk in the Chinese financial system.

headline: Maybe the Wrong Knicks Are Shooting (and Missing)
summary: As the Knicks have derailed, so has the Knicks' offense and things are getting a bit wacky. The Knicks' second-class citizens have taken over the offense.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Hitting the Dance Floor
summary: Over the weekend at the famous International Red Cross Ball in Palm Beach, Fla., the Peter Duchin Orchestra barely had three notes out and suddenly the dance floor was toe-to-toe, shoulder-to-shoulder.
